CLAM

clam.data

Data loading, processing, and embedding utilities.

Dataset Loading

Dataset loading and preparation utilities.

clam.data.dataset.silence_pandas_warning(func, *args, **kwargs)[source]

Execute a function with pandas warnings temporarily silenced.

clam.data.dataset.list_available_datasets() → Dict[str, int][source]

Returns a dictionary of predefined OpenML dataset names and their IDs. These datasets are known to work well with CLAM.

Returns:

Dictionary mapping dataset names to their OpenML IDs

clam.data.dataset.get_dataset_info(dataset_id_or_name: str | int) → Dict[str, Any][source]

Get information about a dataset from OpenML without loading the actual data.

Parameters:

dataset_id_or_name – ID or name of the dataset to get info about

Returns:

Dictionary with dataset information including name, ID, feature count, sample count, target feature, etc.

clam.data.dataset.load_dataset(dataset_name: str, bypass_size_check: bool = False, preserve_regression: bool = False) → Tuple[ndarray, ndarray, List[bool], List[str], str][source]

Load a dataset from OpenML. Can load datasets by name or ID.

Parameters:

  • dataset_name – Name or ID of the dataset to load. If using a name, it can be one of the predefined datasets (use list_available_datasets() to see options) or any other OpenML dataset name. If using an ID, it should be a string representation of the OpenML dataset ID (e.g., ‘1169’ for Airlines).

  • bypass_size_check – If True, bypasses the minimum 1000 samples requirement. Default is False.

  • preserve_regression – If True, preserves continuous targets for regression tasks instead of converting them to classification. Default is False.

Returns:

Features y: Labels categorical_indicator: Boolean list indicating categorical features attribute_names: List of feature names dataset_name: Full name of the dataset

Return type:

X

clam.data.dataset.clear_failed_dataset_cache() → None[source]

Clear the cache of failed dataset IDs.

clam.data.dataset.get_failed_dataset_ids() → List[int][source]

Get the list of dataset IDs that have failed to load.

clam.data.dataset.analyze_dataset(X_train: ndarray, y_train: ndarray, X_val: ndarray, y_val: ndarray, X_test: ndarray, y_test: ndarray) → Tuple[Dict, Dict, Dict][source]

Analyze the class distribution in the dataset splits.

Parameters:

  • X_train – Training features

  • y_train – Training labels

  • X_val – Validation features

  • y_val – Validation labels

  • X_test – Test features

  • y_test – Test labels

Returns:

Class distribution in training set val_counts: Class distribution in validation set test_counts: Class distribution in test set

Return type:

train_counts

clam.data.dataset.create_llm_dataset(X_train: ndarray, y_train: ndarray, X_val: ndarray, y_val: ndarray, X_test: ndarray, y_test: ndarray, train_embeddings: ndarray, val_embeddings: ndarray, test_embeddings: ndarray, tokenizer: Any, prefix_start_id: int, prefix_end_id: int, class_token_ids: List[int], output_dir: str | None = None, num_few_shot_examples: int = 100, max_train_samples: int | None = None, max_test_samples: int | None = None) → Tuple[Dataset, Dataset, Dataset, LabelEncoder, str][source]

Create LLM datasets with TabPFN embeddings as prefix.

Parameters:

  • X_train – Training features

  • y_train – Training labels

  • X_val – Validation features

  • y_val – Validation labels

  • X_test – Test features

  • y_test – Test labels

  • train_embeddings – TabPFN embeddings for training set

  • val_embeddings – TabPFN embeddings for validation set

  • test_embeddings – TabPFN embeddings for test set

  • tokenizer – Tokenizer for the LLM

  • prefix_start_id – Token ID for prefix start marker

  • prefix_end_id – Token ID for prefix end marker

  • class_token_ids – List of token IDs for class tokens

  • output_dir – Directory to save prefix data

  • num_few_shot_examples – Number of few-shot examples to include in the prefix (configurable at inference time)

  • max_train_samples – Maximum number of training samples to use (None for no limit)

  • max_test_samples – Maximum number of test and validation samples to use (None for no limit)

Returns:

Training dataset eval_dataset: Evaluation dataset test_dataset: Test dataset label_encoder: Label encoder for class labels prefix_data_file: Path to the saved prefix data

Return type:

train_dataset

clam.data.dataset.load_datasets(args)[source]

Load datasets based on command line arguments.

Embedding Generation

Tabular, image, and audio embedding extraction and processing utilities.

clam.data.embeddings.generate_dataset_hash(X: ndarray, y: ndarray, embedding_size: int, dataset_name: str = None) → str[source]

Generate a unique hash for a dataset configuration based on its properties.

Parameters:

  • X – Feature matrix

  • y – Labels

  • embedding_size – Size of the embeddings to be generated

  • dataset_name – Optional name of the dataset

Returns:

A unique string hash for this dataset configuration

Return type:

hash_str

clam.data.embeddings.get_tabpfn_embeddings(X_train: ndarray, y_train: ndarray, X_val: ndarray, X_test: ndarray, max_samples: int = 3000, embedding_size: int = 1000, cache_dir: str | None = None, dataset_name: str | None = None, force_recompute: bool = False, task_type: str = 'classification', seed: int = 42) → Tuple[ndarray, ndarray, ndarray, Any, ndarray][source]

Get TabPFN embeddings with improved class balance checking and caching.

Parameters:

  • X_train – Training features

  • y_train – Training labels

  • X_val – Validation features

  • X_test – Test features

  • max_samples – Maximum number of samples to use from training set

  • embedding_size – Size of the output embeddings

  • cache_dir – Directory to store cached embeddings. If None, caching is disabled.

  • dataset_name – Optional name of the dataset for the cache filename

  • force_recompute – If True, ignore cache and recompute embeddings

  • task_type – Type of task - “classification” or “regression”

  • seed – Random seed for reproducible feature selection and sampling

Returns:

TabPFN embeddings for training set val_embeddings: TabPFN embeddings for validation set test_embeddings: TabPFN embeddings for test set tabpfn: Fitted TabPFN model y_train_sample: Labels for the sampled training set

Return type:

train_embeddings

clam.data.embeddings.get_embeddings_in_chunks(model: Any, X: ndarray, dataset_name: str = 'dataset', max_chunk_size: int = 3000, embedding_method: Callable[[Any, ndarray], ndarray] | None = None) → ndarray[source]

Process embeddings for larger datasets in chunks to avoid memory issues.

This function is designed to process large datasets in manageable chunks, reducing memory usage and preventing out-of-memory errors. It’s particularly useful for validation and test sets that might be too large to process at once.

Parameters:

  • model – Fitted model with get_embeddings method or custom function

  • X – Feature matrix to get embeddings for

  • dataset_name – Name of the dataset for logging (for informational purposes)

  • max_chunk_size – Maximum number of samples to process in a single chunk

  • embedding_method – Optional custom function to get embeddings (default: model.get_embeddings) If provided, will be called as: embedding_method(model, X_chunk)

Returns:

Processed embeddings as a numpy array

Example

```python # Using default method (model.get_embeddings) val_embeddings = get_embeddings_in_chunks(tabpfn, X_val, “validation”, max_chunk_size=2000)

# Using custom embedding function def custom_embedder(model, data):

return model.embed_data(data, special_flag=True)

test_embeddings = get_embeddings_in_chunks(model, X_test, “test”,

max_chunk_size=1500, embedding_method=custom_embedder)

```

clam.data.embeddings.resize_embeddings(train_embeddings, val_embeddings, test_embeddings, embedding_size)[source]

Helper function to resize embeddings to target size.

clam.data.embeddings.prepare_tabpfn_embeddings_for_prefix(train_embeddings: ndarray, y_train: ndarray, num_embeddings: int = 100, random_state: int | None = None) → Tuple[ndarray, ndarray][source]

Prepare TabPFN embeddings to be used as prefix, sampling from all classes. Ensures the returned class labels match the embeddings.

Parameters:

  • train_embeddings – TabPFN embeddings for train set with shape [n_samples, embedding_dim]

  • y_train – Labels for the corresponding train embeddings

  • num_embeddings – Total number of embeddings to include (not per class)

  • random_state – Random seed for reproducible sampling

Returns:

Array of shape [num_embeddings, embedding_dim] class_labels: Array of shape [num_embeddings] with corresponding labels

Return type:

embeddings

clam.data.embeddings.get_dinov2_embeddings(image_paths: List[str], model_name: str = 'dinov2_vitb14', embedding_size: int = 1000, cache_dir: str | None = None, dataset_name: str | None = None, force_recompute: bool = False, batch_size: int = 32, device: str | None = None) → ndarray[source]

Extract DINOV2 embeddings from a list of image paths.

Parameters:

  • image_paths – List of paths to image files

  • model_name – DINOV2 model variant to use

  • embedding_size – Target size for output embeddings (will resize if needed)

  • cache_dir – Directory to store cached embeddings

  • dataset_name – Name for caching purposes

  • force_recompute – Whether to ignore cache and recompute

  • batch_size – Number of images to process at once

  • device – Device to run inference on

Returns:

Array of shape [n_images, embedding_size]

Return type:

embeddings

clam.data.embeddings.load_dinov2_model(model_name: str = 'dinov2_vitb14', device: str | None = None) → Module[source]

Load a DINOV2 model for image embedding extraction.

Parameters:

  • model_name –

    Name of the DINOV2 model to load. Options: Standard models: - “dinov2_vits14”: ViT-Small with patch size 14 - “dinov2_vitb14”: ViT-Base with patch size 14 - “dinov2_vitl14”: ViT-Large with patch size 14 - “dinov2_vitg14”: ViT-Giant with patch size 14

    Models with registers (improved training stability): - “dinov2_vits14_reg”: ViT-Small with registers - “dinov2_vitb14_reg”: ViT-Base with registers - “dinov2_vitl14_reg”: ViT-Large with registers - “dinov2_vitg14_reg”: ViT-Giant with registers

    Linear classifier variants (with classification head): - “dinov2_vits14_lc”: ViT-Small with linear classifier - “dinov2_vitb14_lc”: ViT-Base with linear classifier - “dinov2_vitl14_lc”: ViT-Large with linear classifier - “dinov2_vitg14_lc”: ViT-Giant with linear classifier

  • device – Device to load the model on. If None, auto-detects GPU/CPU

Returns:

Loaded DINOV2 model

clam.data.embeddings.prepare_image_for_dinov2(image_path: str, size: int = 224) → Tensor[source]

Prepare an image for DINOV2 processing.

Parameters:

  • image_path – Path to the image file

  • size – Target size for the image (DINOV2 expects 224x224)

Returns:

Preprocessed image tensor ready for DINOV2

Audio Processing

Visualization

T-SNE visualization utilities for tabular data embeddings.

clam.data.tsne_visualization.create_tsne_visualization(train_embeddings: ndarray, train_labels: ndarray, test_embeddings: ndarray, test_labels: ndarray | None = None, perplexity: int = 30, n_iter: int = 1000, random_state: int = 42, figsize: Tuple[int, int] = (12, 8), class_names: List[str] | None = None, use_semantic_names: bool = False, use_3d: bool = False) → Tuple[ndarray, ndarray, Figure][source]

Create t-SNE visualization of train and test embeddings.

Parameters:

  • train_embeddings – Training embeddings [n_train, embedding_dim]

  • train_labels – Training labels [n_train]

  • test_embeddings – Test embeddings [n_test, embedding_dim]

  • test_labels – Optional test labels for validation [n_test]

  • perplexity – t-SNE perplexity parameter

  • n_iter – Number of t-SNE iterations

  • random_state – Random seed for reproducibility

  • figsize – Figure size (width, height)

  • class_names – Optional class names for labeling

  • use_semantic_names – Whether to use semantic class names

  • use_3d – Whether to create 3D visualization (default: False for 2D)

Returns:

t-SNE coordinates for training data [n_train, 2 or 3] test_tsne: t-SNE coordinates for test data [n_test, 2 or 3] fig: Matplotlib figure object (2D or 3D depending on use_3d)

Return type:

train_tsne

clam.data.tsne_visualization.create_tsne_3d_visualization(train_embeddings: ndarray, train_labels: ndarray, test_embeddings: ndarray, test_labels: ndarray | None = None, perplexity: int = 30, n_iter: int = 1000, random_state: int = 42, figsize: Tuple[int, int] = (15, 12), class_names: List[str] | None = None, use_semantic_names: bool = False) → Tuple[ndarray, ndarray, Figure][source]

Create 3D t-SNE visualization of train and test embeddings.

Parameters:

  • train_embeddings – Training embeddings [n_train, embedding_dim]

  • train_labels – Training labels [n_train]

  • test_embeddings – Test embeddings [n_test, embedding_dim]

  • test_labels – Optional test labels for validation [n_test]

  • perplexity – t-SNE perplexity parameter

  • n_iter – Number of t-SNE iterations

  • random_state – Random seed for reproducibility

  • figsize – Figure size (width, height)

Returns:

3D t-SNE coordinates for training data [n_train, 3] test_tsne: 3D t-SNE coordinates for test data [n_test, 3] fig: Matplotlib figure object with 3D subplot

Return type:

train_tsne

clam.data.tsne_visualization.create_class_legend(unique_classes: ndarray, class_color_map: Dict, class_names: List[str] | None = None, use_semantic_names: bool = False) → str[source]

Create a text legend describing class colors with both semantic names and RGB values.

Parameters:

  • unique_classes – Array of unique class labels

  • class_color_map – Dictionary mapping class labels to colors

  • class_names – Optional list of semantic class names

  • use_semantic_names – Whether to show semantic names in legend

Returns:

String description of the color legend

Return type:

legend_text

clam.data.tsne_visualization.create_combined_tsne_plot(train_tsne: ndarray, test_tsne: ndarray, train_labels: ndarray, highlight_test_idx: int | None = None, figsize: Tuple[int, int] = (10, 8), zoom_factor: float = 2.0, class_names: List[str] | None = None, use_semantic_names: bool = False, use_3d: bool = False) → Tuple[Figure, str, Dict][source]

Create a t-SNE plot with optional highlighting of a specific test point.

Parameters:

  • train_tsne – t-SNE coordinates for training data [n_train, 2 or 3]

  • test_tsne – t-SNE coordinates for test data [n_test, 2 or 3]

  • train_labels – Training labels [n_train]

  • highlight_test_idx – Index of test point to highlight (optional)

  • figsize – Figure size (width, height)

  • zoom_factor – Zoom level (2.0 = 200% zoom, showing 50% of the range)

  • class_names – Optional class names for labeling

  • use_semantic_names – Whether to use semantic class names

  • use_3d – Whether to create 3D visualization (default: False for 2D)

Returns:

Matplotlib figure object (2D or 3D depending on use_3d) legend_text: Text description of the legend metadata: Dictionary with plot metadata

Return type:

fig

clam.data.tsne_visualization.create_combined_tsne_3d_plot(train_tsne: ndarray, test_tsne: ndarray, train_labels: ndarray, highlight_test_idx: int | None = None, figsize: Tuple[int, int] = (20, 15), viewing_angles: List[Tuple[int, int]] | None = None, zoom_factor: float = 2.0, class_names: List[str] | None = None, use_semantic_names: bool = False) → Tuple[Figure, str, Dict][source]

Create multiple 3D t-SNE plots with different viewing angles for comprehensive spatial understanding.

Parameters:

  • train_tsne – 3D t-SNE coordinates for training data [n_train, 3]

  • test_tsne – 3D t-SNE coordinates for test data [n_test, 3]

  • train_labels – Training labels [n_train]

  • highlight_test_idx – Index of test point to highlight (optional)

  • figsize – Figure size (width, height)

  • viewing_angles – List of (elevation, azimuth) tuples for different views

  • zoom_factor – Zoom level (2.0 = 200% zoom, showing 50% of the range)

Returns:

Matplotlib figure object with multiple 3D subplots legend_text: Text description of the legend metadata: Dictionary with plot metadata

Return type:

fig

clam.data.tsne_visualization.create_tsne_plot_with_knn(train_tsne: ndarray, test_tsne: ndarray, train_labels: ndarray, train_embeddings: ndarray, test_embeddings: ndarray, highlight_test_idx: int | None = None, k: int = 5, figsize: Tuple[int, int] = (14, 10), zoom_factor: float = 2.0, class_names: List[str] | None = None, use_semantic_names: bool = False) → Tuple[Figure, str, Dict][source]

Create a 2D t-SNE plot with KNN pie chart showing neighbor class distribution.

Parameters:

  • train_tsne – 2D t-SNE coordinates for training data [n_train, 2]

  • test_tsne – 2D t-SNE coordinates for test data [n_test, 2]

  • train_labels – Training labels [n_train]

  • train_embeddings – Original training embeddings for KNN [n_train, embedding_dim]

  • test_embeddings – Original test embeddings for KNN [n_test, embedding_dim]

  • highlight_test_idx – Index of test point to highlight and show KNN pie chart

  • k – Number of nearest neighbors to analyze

  • figsize – Figure size (width, height)

  • zoom_factor – Zoom level (2.0 = 200% zoom, showing 50% of the range)

Returns:

Matplotlib figure object legend_text: Text description of the legend metadata: Dictionary with plot metadata

Return type:

fig

clam.data.tsne_visualization.create_tsne_3d_plot_with_knn(train_tsne: ndarray, test_tsne: ndarray, train_labels: ndarray, train_embeddings: ndarray, test_embeddings: ndarray, highlight_test_idx: int | None = None, k: int = 5, figsize: Tuple[int, int] = (20, 15), viewing_angles: List[Tuple[int, int]] | None = None, zoom_factor: float = 2.0, class_names: List[str] | None = None, use_semantic_names: bool = False) → Tuple[Figure, str, Dict][source]

Create multiple 3D t-SNE plots with KNN pie chart from different viewing angles.

  • train_labels – Training labels [n_train]

  • train_embeddings – Original training embeddings for KNN [n_train, embedding_dim]

  • test_embeddings – Original test embeddings for KNN [n_test, embedding_dim]

  • highlight_test_idx – Index of test point to highlight and show KNN pie chart

  • k – Number of nearest neighbors to analyze

  • figsize – Figure size (width, height)

  • viewing_angles – List of (elevation, azimuth) tuples for different views

  • zoom_factor – Zoom level (2.0 = 200% zoom, showing 50% of the range)

Returns:

Matplotlib figure object with multiple 3D subplots legend_text: Text description of the legend metadata: Dictionary with plot metadata

clam.data.tsne_visualization.create_regression_tsne_visualization(train_embeddings: ndarray, train_targets: ndarray, test_embeddings: ndarray, test_targets: ndarray | None = None, perplexity: int = 30, n_iter: int = 1000, random_state: int = 42, figsize: Tuple[int, int] = (12, 8), colormap: str = 'viridis') → Tuple[ndarray, ndarray, Figure][source]

Create t-SNE visualization for regression data with continuous color mapping.

Parameters:

  • train_embeddings – Training embeddings [n_train, embedding_dim]

  • train_targets – Training target values [n_train]

  • test_embeddings – Test embeddings [n_test, embedding_dim]

  • test_targets – Optional test target values [n_test]

  • perplexity – t-SNE perplexity parameter

  • n_iter – Number of t-SNE iterations

  • random_state – Random seed for reproducibility

  • figsize – Figure size (width, height)

  • colormap – Matplotlib colormap name for target values

Returns:

2D t-SNE coordinates for training data [n_train, 2] test_tsne: 2D t-SNE coordinates for test data [n_test, 2] fig: Matplotlib figure object

Return type:

train_tsne

clam.data.tsne_visualization.create_regression_tsne_plot_with_knn(train_tsne: ndarray, test_tsne: ndarray, train_targets: ndarray, train_embeddings: ndarray, test_embeddings: ndarray, highlight_test_idx: int = 0, k: int = 5, figsize: Tuple[int, int] = (10, 8), zoom_factor: float = 1.0, colormap: str = 'RdBu_r') → Tuple[Figure, str, Dict][source]

Create regression t-SNE plot with KNN connections showing target values.

This is a placeholder that calls the base regression plot. Full KNN implementation would require adapting the KNN logic for regression.

clam.data.tsne_visualization.create_regression_tsne_3d_plot_with_knn(train_tsne: ndarray, test_tsne: ndarray, train_targets: ndarray, train_embeddings: ndarray, test_embeddings: ndarray, highlight_test_idx: int = 0, k: int = 5, figsize: Tuple[int, int] = (12, 9), viewing_angles: List[Tuple[int, int]] | None = None, zoom_factor: float = 1.0, colormap: str = 'RdBu_r') → Tuple[Figure, str, Dict][source]

Create 3D regression t-SNE plot with KNN connections showing target values.

This is a placeholder that calls the base 3D regression plot. Full KNN implementation would require adapting the KNN logic for regression.

clam.data.tsne_visualization.create_regression_color_map(target_values: ndarray, colormap: str = 'RdBu_r', n_levels: int = 20) → Tuple[ndarray, Colormap, float, float][source]

Create a discrete red-blue colormap for regression target values.

Blue represents minimum values, red represents maximum values. Uses 20+ discrete levels for fine-grained VLM estimation.

Parameters:

  • target_values – Array of target values

  • colormap – Name of matplotlib colormap to use (default: ‘RdBu_r’ for red-blue)

  • n_levels – Number of discrete color levels (default: 20)

Returns:

Tuple of (normalized_values, colormap_object, vmin, vmax)

Utilities

Utilities for loading and handling CSV datasets with precomputed embeddings.

clam.data.csv_utils.is_csv_dataset(dataset_id: str) → bool[source]

Determine if a dataset ID corresponds to a CSV dataset rather than an OpenML dataset.

Parameters:

dataset_id – The dataset identifier

Returns:

True if this appears to be a CSV dataset, False if it’s likely an OpenML dataset

clam.data.csv_utils.find_csv_file(dataset_id: str, search_dirs: List[str]) → str | None[source]

Search for a CSV file in multiple directories. Uses robust resource manager search strategy with fallback to legacy method.

Parameters:

  • dataset_id – The dataset identifier

  • search_dirs – List of directories to search in

Returns:

Path to the CSV file if found, None otherwise

clam.data.csv_utils.load_csv_dataset(file_path: str) → Tuple[ndarray, ndarray, List[bool], List[str], str][source]

Load a dataset from a CSV file. Handles both single CSV files with features+labels and separate X/y files.

Parameters:

file_path – Path to the CSV file

Returns:

Features y: Labels categorical_indicator: Boolean list indicating categorical features attribute_names: List of feature names dataset_name: Name of the dataset (derived from file name)

Return type:

X

clam.data.csv_utils.find_csv_with_fallbacks(dataset_id: str, primary_dir: str | None = None, data_dir: str | None = None, embed_dir: str | None = None) → str | None[source]

Find a CSV file using multiple fallback directories. Uses the new resource manager for robust path resolution.

Parameters:

  • dataset_id – The dataset identifier

  • primary_dir – Primary directory to search (e.g., current embedding directory)

  • data_dir – Data directory specified by user (e.g., –data_dir)

  • embed_dir – Embedding directory

Returns:

Path to the CSV file if found, None otherwise
